Topic: Draw reversible and irreversible changes (ice melting vs. egg cooking)
Evidence Statements: The student can draw the original state of a material before heating or cooling, such as a whole ice cube or raw egg.
The student can illustrate what the material looks like after it has been heated or cooled, such as melted water from an ice cube or a cooked egg.
The student can show if the change can be reversed by drawing the reverse process, like freezing water back into ice.
The student can depict that some changes cannot be reversed, such as a cooked egg that cannot be returned to its raw state.
The student can use arrows or symbols to show cause and effect, indicating how heating or cooling causes the change in the materials.
The student can use labels or captions to explain whether the change they have drawn is reversible or irreversible.
